streaming server really helps deliver that live stream to your viewers or specifically the players on your viewers
devices is by generating short chunks of the live video that the
players can play so and in addition to those short chunks the streaming server is also generating
a manifest file which then the manifest file points the player to the location
where it can get the next chunk with the next few seconds of live
video from so the media server is really continuously creating these manifest
files and the chunks that create the effect of a live playback experience for your viewers on
their on their players whatever devices they have to be on so so in terms of you know what that
means for the role of the server the media server itself the media server is taking as input the stream
that's coming out of the encoder on site where your where your live production is happening
the media server is transcoding that stream to different bit rates it's also transmission to different
delivery protocols again so that different devices can be supported
because you know there is a varied range of protocols that are supported on different devices
and and finally generating and updating that that manifest file that helps the player
find the the next chunk
the third piece of the architecture is uh actually delivering it out to your viewers globally
um you know and and this is where you need a high performance delivery mechanism so that you can deliver the
best possible quality video to your global audience so one solution here is the the amazon
cloudfront global content delivery network where we have 43 edge locations or points of presence
around the world today that can that can act as the first points that
the players or your viewers talk to and then those edge locations will go back to the
the origin server or the media server running on ec2 that has those chunks and the manifest files download them and

locations has worldwide platform supports all of the http based
streaming protocols so hls hds smooth and so on platform also helps improve performance
for your live event and the streaming of your live event and what i mean there is there are a
couple of cloudfront optimizations such as persistent connections and other tcp optimizations
that are that are that we have implemented between cloud finance locations and the origin server
or the media server running in ec2 that really help the performance
and the scalability of delivering your live video the performance because of the
persistent connections it helps minimize the connection setup time between the edge location and your origin server
and and that helps faster download of the next update to the manifest file or
the next chunk that becomes available at the origin server
cloudfront also presents the cost savings uh you know cloud platform is priced the same way as other aws

we have a pay for what you use in pay as you go pricing and platform also follows that and this becomes you know even more

bring up a stack of you know different aws services uh and a media server running on ec2 to

so it's it's really the challenges uh stem from the fact that uh you know
live events are very dynamic in nature um live streaming can [Music]
does need to scale you know when you're streaming your event live you can have any number of viewers and it's usually hard to predict
how many viewers you will have uh watching your live event and your event could go viral at any point in
time so the ability to handle those flash crowds the ability to protect and shield
your media server your origin servers from spikes even if you have a large
number of people now interested in viewing your live event and yet ensuring that every single
viewer gets the best possible experience so that that can be a daunting challenge um
when you're when you're delivering an event live also the cost-effective
uh cost-effectiveness or the cost of delivering a live event um you know because events are
um often live events are often sporadic um or they need uh you know you need to
account for the maximum number of users or viewers and it's often not easy to

if you're not using a scalable cloud solution fairly cost efficient inefficient
and uh on the other hand if you're if you're running out of capacity because you didn't plan correctly and you don't
have enough capacity then you're delivering a poor experience for your viewers um when you have a flash card and when
you or when you have an increased interest in your live event and then finally the viewers your
viewers can come from anywhere you know so just having the ability to deliver
your live stream globally with the best possible performance using
a global cdn can you know that sort of
that can really help mitigate that challenge because you know you may be targeting a specific audience but that doesn't necessarily
mean that your viewers are not located you know outside of that geographic region
and then the other challenge is really around the the fragmented ecosystem of devices codecs protocols uh you know
when it comes to delivering your live stream seamlessly to every potential viewer out there um you know this can
this can be a big challenge so you know you have to really question yourself do i need to support
silverlight or webm or both do i need to optimize uh you know my content for smartphones
uh tablets desktops game consoles where are these viewers watching my live stream from and it could be any one of

you consume when you're delivering your live event and you don't pay for the time you know
when the event is after the time that the event is over and you know you're not consuming those resources anymore
so it converts your capital expense that you may have had to spend if you were to do this all in house and buy capacity
for the maximum number of viewers you need to support into an operating expense now you know
on a per event basis where you're only really scaling up for the duration of the event and then scaling back down
the other thing that i that i want to call out is the ease of setup and and also tear down

first question we have for nihar given that live streams are real time in
nature how important are the caching benefits in live streaming scenario versus on demand
sure uh yeah that's a great question uh you know given that live streams are real time
there's still benefits of using cloudfront and caching those chunks that uh that the
the the media server the adobe media server will uh produce um and that's because
cloudfront has a couple of different features the first being what we call internally collapse
forwarding where if we receive uh hundreds or thousands of viewers
which is normal for a live event come to a single edge location or a single platform edge node we will collapse all
of those requests and send a single request back to the origin server and then cache that response from the origin
server so that all subsequent viewers can be can receive that cache response
that helps reduce load on the latency load on the origin server as well as
reduce latency for for viewers uh you know who are getting the cached version of that of that response who may just be
you know a few milliseconds or tens of milliseconds behind some of the other viewers so that's that's the the big
advantage the the second thing i'd say is the persistent connections that's more of a performance benefit where i as i explained
cloudfront maintains persistent connections between the edge servers and the origin servers
so that you know connection doesn't need to be established re-established each time for
each viewer so that's another added benefit to help you you know
shield your origin servers okay thanks uh chris could you answer this

sure there's a couple of different ways actually that you could get reporting or metrics and data on your viewers
so first is cloudfront access logs and cloudfront will produce access logs for each
request that platform receives for a file or an object that is downloaded via our http network so these access logs
are available in an amazon s3 packet so you can download the access logs from there and process them or you can use a
third-party tool and that tool can process these standardized log files to give you the
insights that you need about your viewers and about your content the second method is using the player
and players are often instrumented with you know capability to report
collect metrics and report them back to a central location and then you can gather insights and
receive reports from uh from the player's perspective from the viewer's perspective uh
data about your viewers as well as about the quality of the stream that they received

device like a tivo at home it's basically the easiest way to say a digital video recorder when you can
pause a stream you can go backwards in a stream or if you come in late to a program or a live event you
can actually rewind it to the beginning and start from the beginning and then perhaps over time if there are some slow spots you can actually catch back up to
the live feed and so that's one of the capabilities that is provided with wild media server and works across
cloudfront there's also transcoding which is as i mentioned earlier that capability of
bringing in a stream from an encoder that either uses different codecs than those used by hls hds and smooth and we
transcode to h.264 video and aac audio and then repackage the content for each
of those formats or it can also be used for the trans rating aspect which is creating
